Enamora Air Supply en México
Los australianos volvieron por sexta ocasión al Auditorio Nacional, ahora con su show The lost in love experience
03 Nov 2019 by Adolfo López | El Sol de México
El romance es lo que enmarca las canciones de Air Supply. Y ese fue el mismo sentimiento que transmitieron este fin de semana que la banda australiana se presentó por sexta ocasión en su carrera en el Auditorio Nacional.
Russell Hitchcock y Graham Russell, quienes forman esta dupla desde 1976, cautivaron a su público con un recorrido por sus canciones que comenzó a las 20:38 horas con Sweet dreams .
   •  Al cine la vida y obra de Bee Gees
"Gracias damas y caballeros. Bienvenidos a este show, es un honor estar con ustedes. Nunca hemos dado nada por sentado y agradecemos estar con ustedes esta noche", dijo Russel tras poner a gritar al público con sus clásicas canciones Even the nights are better, Just as I am y Every woman in the world .
Visiblemente emocionados, el dueto recorrió de lado a lado el escenario. Russel Hitchcock bailaba dando brinquitos, mientras Graham tocaba la guitarra e interpretaba al mismo tiempo Chances , Here I am o Lost in love , una de las más aplaudidas de la noche.
Pero fue la entrega al público lo que cautivó la velada. Y es que el grupo cantó el tema The one that you love recorriendo los pasillos del Auditorio Nacional, provocando gritos de emoción y una multitud que apenas los dejaba moverse, pues todos querían estar cerca de ellos.
La sobriedad del concierto se convirtió al poco tiempo en una auténtica fiesta que puso de pie a cientos de fans. Muchos de ellos burlaron la seguridad del recinto y acabaron frente al escenario.
Air Supply se dejó querer, tocando la mano de algunos afortunados, mientras cantaban con toda energía temas como Without you , Shake it y All out of love , con el que se despidieron tras 90 minutos

Enamora Air Supply in Mexico
The Australians returned for the sixth time to the National Auditorium, now with their show The lost in love experience
03 Nov 2019 by Adolfo López | The sun of Mexico
Romance is what frames the songs of Air Supply. And that was the same feeling they conveyed this weekend that the Australian band performed for the sixth time in their career at the National Auditorium.
Russell Hitchcock and Graham Russell, who form this duo since 1976, captivated their audience with a tour of their songs that began at 8:38 p.m. with Sweet dreams.
• To the cinema the life and work of Bee Gees
"Thank you ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to this show, it is an honor to be with you. We have never taken anything for granted and we are grateful to be with you tonight," Russel said after shouting at the audience with his classic songs Even the nights are better. , Just as I am and Every woman in the world.
Visibly excited, the duet toured the stage from side to side. Russel Hitchcock danced, while Graham played the guitar and performed at the same time Chances, Here I am or Lost in love, one of the most applauded of the night.
But it was the delivery to the public that captivated the evening. And the group sang the song The one that you love walking the halls of the National Auditorium, causing shouts of emotion and a crowd that barely let them move, because everyone wanted to be close to them.
The sobriety of the concert soon became a real party that stood up to hundreds of fans. Many of them mocked the security of the enclosure and ended up facing the stage.
Air Supply let itself be loved, touching the hands of some lucky ones, while singing with all energy songs like Without you, Shake it and All out of love, with which they said goodbye after 90 minutes
